title: Advances in Delta-md measurements
summary:
We report the current status of Delta-md measurements at B-factories. The
most recent world average is Delta-md = 0.502+-0.007 1/ps (1.4% accuracy). An
estimate of the errors for 500 1/fb data is also given.

summary_detail.value:
We report the current status of Delta-md measurements at B-factories. The
most recent world average is Delta-md = 0.502+-0.007 1/ps (1.4% accuracy). An
estimate of the errors for 500 1/fb data is also given.

author: Frederic Jean Ronga

  Durham, April 2003 (eConf C0304052). 4 pages LaTeX, 6 eps figures
fulltext:
Workshop on the CKM Unitarity Triangle, IPPP Durham, April 2003

CKM03
Advances in ∆md measurements
F J Ronga

We report the current status of ∆md measurements at B-factories. The most recent world average is ∆md = 0.502 ± 0.007 ps−1 (1.4%
accuracy). An estimate of the errors for 500 fb−1 data is also given.

2 Dilepton measurement

In the Standard Model, B0 -B0 oscillations occur through
second-order weak interactions, mainly through internal
loops containing virtual t quarks. The mixing parameter
∆md , the mass difference between the two mass eigenstates, is thus related to the Vtb and Vtd CKM matrix elements. The measurement of ∆md can therefore in principle
provide a means to extract |Vtd |. In addition, ∆md plays a
role in the parameterization of the CP asymmetries in the
B0 system: a precise measurement of ∆md is also needed
for CP violation measurements (see [1,2]).

In this analysis [4,5], semi-leptonic decays B → X − l+ νl
from both B mesons are used to tag the B flavor with
the sign of the lepton. Two fast leptons are searched for.
The decay vertex position of the B meson is determined
from the interception of the lepton track with the profile
of the interaction point. Because of the large semi-leptonic
branching fraction, this analysis offers the largest statistics.
However, the purity of the signal is affected by the background coming from charged B mesons.

POF (∆t)
PSF (∆t)

Events / 0.24 ps

In this article, we present different measurements of ∆md
from the time distributions of opposite-flavor (OF – B0 B0 )
and same-flavor (SF – B0 B0 , B0 B0 ) neutral B decays at the
Υ(4S ) resonance. The theoretical time-dependent probabilities for observing OF and SF states are given by:

Events / 0.24 ps

1 Introduction

4τB0
(1)

where τB0 is the B0 lifetime and ∆t is the proper time difference between the two B meson decays. This assumes CP
and CPT conservation in the mixing, as well as negligible
∆Γ (decay width difference between the two B meson mass
eigenstates).
The analyses presented here were performed on data collected with the BaBar and the Belle detectors [3]. A 9 GeV
(resp. 8 GeV) electron beam and a 3.1 GeV (resp. 3.5 GeV)
positron beam are collided in the PEPII (resp. KEKB)
storage ring, resulting in a Lorentz boost of the centerof-mass of βγ = 0.55 (resp. 0.425) with respect to the
laboratory frame. Since B mesons are nearly at rest in the
Υ(4S ) frame, the proper time difference ∆t is approximated
by ∆z/βγc, ∆z being the (signed) distance between the decay vertices of the two B mesons along the beam axis. The
flavor of the B mesons is determined using flavor-specific
decays.

This selection has been applied on 20 fb−1 on-resonance
data from BaBar (about 22 million B meson pairs), yielding
∆md = 0.493 ± 0.012 ± 0.009 ps−1 (see Fig. 1, also showing
the mixing asymmetry (NOF − NSF )/(NOF + NSF )). Belle
obtains ∆md = 0.503 ± 0.008 ± 0.010 ps−1 from 29.4 fb−1
on-resonance data (see Fig. 2). At present, the latter is the

3

D∗ π partial reconstruction

Belle uses another partial reconstruction method [6] to extract ∆md from B0 → D∗− π+f decays. The D∗− information
is extrapolated from the soft pion of D∗− → D0 π−s , and
then combined with the fast pion π+f and the beam information to reconstruct the B meson. The flavor is given by
the charge of the fast pion. The other side is tagged by
simply looking for a fast lepton. 31 fb−1 on-resonance data
was used in this measurement.
Contributions of various backgrounds can be estimated
from the D0 "missing mass" (see Fig. 3). A simultaneous unbinned maximum likelihood fit to OF and SF events
yields: ∆md = 0.509 ± 0.017 ± 0.020 ps−1 .

4

D∗ l ν full reconstruction

This method [7,8] fully reconstructs B0 → D∗− l+ ν, with
D∗− → D0 π− and D0 → K + π− , K + π− π0 , or K + π− π+ π−
(BaBar also reconstructs K s π+ π− ). The flavor of the
other B meson is tagged using the same algorithms as in
Ref. [1,2] (a neural network for BaBar, a multidimensional
likelihood for Belle).
The cosine of the angle between the reconstructed D∗ l system and the B meson momenta in the Υ(4S ) frame is used
to separate the signal from various backgrounds (D∗∗ , fake
D∗ , random D∗ l and continuum). An unbinned maximum
likelihood fit is then performed on the ∆z distributions.
The results of the fit by BaBar, shown on Fig. 4, yields

∆md = 0.492 ± 0.018 ± 0.013 ps−1 (from 20 fb−1 ). Belle
obtains ∆md = 0.494 ± 0.012 ± 0.015 ps−1 from 29 fb−1 .

5 Hadronic modes
The exclusive reconstruction of B mesons decaying into
flavor specific hadronic states has also been used to measure ∆md [9,10]. Neutral B mesons are reconstructed in
the decay modes D(∗)+ π− and D(∗)+ ρ− (and also D(∗)+ a−1
by BaBar), with D∗+ decaying into D0 π+ and D0 decaying
into K − π+ , K − π+ π0 or K − π+ π− π+ (or also K s π+ in BaBar's
case). The ρ− and a−1 are formed of π0 π− and π− π+ π− , respectively. Finally, BaBar also includes B0 decaying into
J/ψK ∗0 . The other side is tagged using a flavour tagging
algorithm, as in the previous analysis (see [1,2]).

Fig. 7 shows the most up-to-date summary of the results, as
selected for the 2003 issue of the PDG review. The world
average is: ∆md = 0.502 ± 0.007 ps−1 [12] (including statistical and systematical errors), with an accuracy of 1.4%.

BaBar performs an unbinned likelihood fit including resolution parameters on 30 fb−1 on-resonance data and finds
∆md = 0.516 ± 0.016 ± 0.010. Belle uses the resolution function used for lifetime measurements [11] and obtains ∆md = 0.528 ± 0.017 ± 0.011 ps−1 from 29 fb−1 onresonance data (see Fig. 6).

Within 3 years, BaBar and Belle will have collected
500 fb−1 each (about 15 times more than what was used
here). An extrapolation of the systematic errors for each
individual measurement has been made in order to estimate
the accuracy on ∆md that could be reached. Improvement
of the current limiting systematic errors are evaluated from:
a better precision on the B lifetime, a larger amount of
Monte-Carlo statistics, an accurate measurement of some
branching fractions (e.g. B → D∗∗ l ν). In addition, resolution parameters are expected to be better extracted from
data. The average value is then computed in the same way
as for the world average, with the central value fixed to
the present average. A total error of 0.0023 ps−1 is found,
which corresponds to 0.5% of 0.502 ps−1 .
These extrapolations do not take into account possible improvements of the existing analyses. On the other hand, the
evolution of systematic errors is hard to predict. This 0.5%
accuracy should therefore be treated carefully.

7 Conclusion
A number of measurements of ∆md have been performed
by the BaBar and Belle collaborations. These efforts have
lead to a world average of ∆md = 0.502 ± 0.007 ps−1 . The

 4

Workshop on the CKM Unitarity Triangle, IPPP Durham, April 2003

error takes into account statistical and systematical correlations between the measurements. The current accuracy on
∆md is currently 1.4%, and is expected to reduce to about
half a percent within a few years.
In the future, ∆m s will be measured with high precision.
The error on ∆md may then become a limiting factor on
the determination of related CKM matrix parameters (see
discussion in [13], chapters 4 and 5). In the meanwhile,
as the accuracy on ∆md is approaching the percent level,
efforts are moving to more fundamental tests of underlying assumptions. Limits on CPT violating parameters have
been set [5], and measurements of ∆Γ have started [14].
